It's different from engines that use fuel like gasoline or steam.

An external combustion engine (EC engine) is a type of engine where the fuel is burned outside the engine, either through the engine wall or a heat exchanger. This heats up a working fluid inside the engine. When the fluid expands, it makes the engine move and creates energy. After that, the fluid is cooled, compressed, and reused in the engine (closed cycle), or sometimes, it's let out and new cool fluid comes in (open cycle air engine). 
A working fluid is like a helper that moves a machine. It can be either a pressurized gas or liquid, like steam in a steam engine or air in a hot air balloon. Question: Which case was decided first, Selle v. Gibb or Reynolds v. Sims? 

 Passage: 
Reynolds v. Sims was a court case in 1964 that said, in simple words, if you want to choose people to represent your state in a group like the Senate, each group (called an electoral district) should have about the same number of people. This was because the court wanted to make sure that big cities and small towns have equal chances. The person who started the case, M.O. Sims, lived in Birmingham, Alabama, but this change affected other states in the South and North too, because they didn't follow this rule for their state legislatures. 
In a big important case called Selle v. Gibb in 1984, the Seventh Circuit Court in the United States decided that when someone copies something, they need to show that they got it. But if there's no proof of how they got it, the court will think it's possible that the person copied because the work is too similar, like it came from the same source. However, just being very similar isn't enough to say they copied. The similarity needs to be so strong that it's impossible for the work to have been made without copying.
West v. Barnes, the first Supreme Court case in the United States, happened in 1791. It was the first case where the Court asked people to speak out (oral argument). A previous case, Van Staphorst v. Maryland, was planned but didn't need to be heard because it was solved before the Court started. West was actually argued and decided very quickly, on August 2 and 3. There was also a case called Collet v. Collet, but it was canceled before it got to be heard. The full opinions from West v. Barnes were not officially written by the Supreme Court reporter, but some parts were shared in newspapers. 
Reynolds v Times Newspapers Ltd was a court case in England about if newspapers could say mean things about people without facing legal trouble if it was important for the public to know. 
George Reynolds was a very important person in the LDS Church. He lived from January 1, 1842 to August 9, 1909. He worked closely with the top leaders of the church and was known for his role as a secretary. He also took part in a big court case in 1878 called Reynolds v. United States, which was the first time the Supreme Court talked about people's freedom to believe in their religion. 
The Jameel vs Wall Street Journal Europe case was a decision made by the House of Lords in England. It confirmed a rule from a previous case called Reynolds v Times Newspapers Ltd. This decision supports having a defense for public interest in cases where someone is accused of defamation. In simpler terms, it means if someone says something true about something important in the public eye, they won't be sued for defamation. 
In Reynolds v. United States, a court case from 1878, the Supreme Court decided that someone cannot say they were doing something because of their religious beliefs as a reason to not be punished by the law. This case was important because it was the first time the court talked about two parts of the Sixth Amendment, which are about having a fair jury and being able to face your accuser in court. 
Morrison Waite, who was Chief Justice of the Supreme Court from 1874 to 1888, had a busy time with criminal cases. In just 14 years, the Supreme Court heard 106 cases, which was almost as many as they had heard before he became the Chief Justice. Some famous cases during this time include Cruikshank, Reese, Reynolds, Wilkerson, Trade-Mark Cases, and many others. These cases dealt with topics like voting rights, state laws, and individual rights.

output: Selle v. Gibb was decided first in 1984, while Reynolds v. Sims was decided in 1964.**

Question: What act for Innocent Records achieved Platinum sales and shares its name with a primary color in the RGB color model? 

 Passage: 
Blue is a color we see between violet and green. When we look at light, blue light is between 450 and 495 tiny parts called nanometres. Blue with shorter wavelength (more like violet) has higher frequency, and the other end, green, has longer wavelength with lower frequency. Pure blue has a wavelength of 470 nanometres. In art, blue is one of three main colors, along with red and yellow, which can make many more colors when mixed together. Red and blue make purple, and blue and yellow make green. Blue is also a key color in something called RGB, which helps make all the colors on a TV or computer screen. 
Innocent Records was a pop music label started by Virgin Records to have more pop acts. After the Spice Girls became popular, Virgin wanted to focus on pop too. They got a man named Hugh Goldsmith from RCA Records, who helped Take That become a big hit. He started a new Virgin label called Innocent. They signed famous people like Billie Piper and Martine McCutcheon, as well as dance groups. The label did well until the mid-2000s with groups like Atomic Kitten and Blue selling a lot of albums.
The ProPhoto RGB color space, called ROMM RGB, is a special color space made by Kodak for pictures. It has a very wide range of colors, perfect for printing photos. It can show almost all the colors in the world, even the ones we see every day, and it also helps to keep the colors true to their original hue. However, not all the colors it can represent are real colors we can see - about 13% of them are not visible. 
The YCoCg color model is a way to change an RGB color into three simpler parts: Y for brightness, Cg for green color, and Co for orange color. It's used in things like video and picture compression because it's easy to work with, helps save space, and can be converted losslessly with fewer bits compared to other color systems. It's found in popular formats like H.264 and JPEG XR. 
A color space is like a way to organize colors, both in real and digital pictures. It helps to make sure everyone sees the same color the same way. Some color spaces use special color swatches and names (like Pantone), while others use math (like RGB or CMYK). A color model is a way to represent colors using numbers, but it's not real until we connect it to a specific color space. A color space is created by connecting a color model to a reference color space, like CIELAB or CIEXYZ, which covers all the colors people can see. Adobe RGB and sRGB are two examples of color spaces based on the RGB model. 
HCL combines features of two color systems, HSL and HSV, which are like cylindrical translations of the RGB color space. These systems are easy to understand because they change RGB colors in a way that people find consistent. However, they don't exactly match how we see brightness. There's another system called L*a*b* that's based on how our eyes see colors, but it can be confusing because the blue part isn't as consistent. In noisy situations, a color system that matches how we see better can perform better than RGB. 
RGBA is short for Red, Green, Blue, and Alpha. It's not a separate color space, but rather uses the RGB color model with an extra part called the alpha channel. This alpha value allows for special effects called alpha compositing. The alpha value comes from a Greek letter used in a math formula to mix colors. 
Brown is a color that comes from mixing other colors. In printing or painting, brown is made with red, black, and yellow, or red, yellow, and blue. On TVs and computers, brown is made from red and green. It's often found in nature, like wood, soil, hair, and skin. Brown can be dark wood or soil color. Surveys show that most people don't like brown, associating it with being plain, country-like, dirty, and poor.

output: The album by the group Blue that achieved Platinum sales and shares its name with a primary color in the RGB color model is "Blue."**

output: The Battle of Manila occurred first, in 1574.**

Question: What produces the hormone that promotes sodium retention in the distal nephron? 

 Passage: 
Angiotensin is a hormone that narrows blood vessels and raises blood pressure. It's part of a system called renin-angiotensin, and doctors often use medicines to target this system for high blood pressure. Angiotensin also makes the adrenal gland release a hormone called aldosterone. Aldosterone helps the body keep more sodium in the kidneys, which in turn makes blood pressure go up. 
Aldosterone is a hormone made by the adrenal gland's zona glomerulosa. It helps keep the body's sodium levels in balance by controlling how much is taken in and removed through the kidneys, salivary glands, sweat glands, and colon. It affects blood pressure by talking to special receptors in the kidneys. When aldosterone isn't working right, it can cause health problems like high blood pressure and heart or kidney issues. It's the opposite of a hormone the heart makes to help reduce sodium and blood pressure.
The Sodium-Chloride Symporter is a special helper in our kidneys that takes in sodium and chloride from the water in our tubes and sends it back into the cells. It's part of a bigger group called SLC12 cotransporters. In people, the gene for this helper is found on chromosome 16, labeled as SLC12A3. 
The loop of Henle, found in the kidney, is a part of a nephron that moves from the top to the bottom part. It's called this because a scientist named Friedrich Henle found it. This loop helps to make the kidney's inside, called the medulla, have different levels of concentration. 
Low pressure receptors, also known as volume receptors, are sensors found in the veins returning blood to the heart (venae cavae), lungs' arteries, and heart's atria. They detect changes in the wall tension, which is related to how full the lower parts of the circulation are (below 60mmHg). These receptors help control the release of hormones like antidiuretic hormone (ADH), renin, and aldosterone.

When the atrial pressure rises, the receptors send signals that reduce the production of ADH and aldosterone. This leads to more urine being produced, which in turn lowers blood pressure. On the other hand, when the atria stretch, they stimulate the release of atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP), which increases the amount of water and sodium being flushed out through the urine, further helping to lower blood pressure. 
Renal tubular acidosis (RTA) is when the body has too much acid because the kidneys can't properly make the urine acidic enough. The kidneys filter blood and remove extra things like salts and acids when it goes through tiny tubes called nephrons. If the kidneys don't keep enough bicarbonate (a base) or make enough hydrogen ions (an acid) in the tubes, it can cause acid buildup. RTA is different from just not having enough kidney function, and there are different types with their own special problems. 
Explanation: The nephron in your kidney has a part called the ascending limb of the loop of Henle. This comes after a bend in the loop, which is after the descending limb. This part of the kidney tubule, which gets bigger, is called both the thick ascending limb and the distal straight tubule, different from the distal convoluted tubule further down. 

 Simplified: The kidney part that follows the bend in the loop is called the ascending limb. It's a bit thicker and is also called the distal straight tubule, not to be confused with the distal convoluted tubule further along. 
Explanation: The kidney has a system called tubuloglomerular feedback (TGF) to control how much water and stuff is filtered out of our blood (glomerular filtration rate, or GFR). Inside each kidney part called a nephron, the tubules, which are further along in the flow, tell the glomerulus, which is at the beginning, what's happening. If the tubules have too much salt, the cells near them release something called adenosine. This starts a chain reaction that adjusts GFR to the right amount. It's all about how the body keeps the right balance.

output: Aldosterone.**
